page.title: 11Marton's Historic Bridge
page.content: The road which runs through Marton is known to have been carried over the River Leam at this point as early as the 13th.Century.Henry 111 committed the Abbot of Sulby the charge of receiving a toll for use of the bridge.The present 15th Century bridge is built of sandstone.It was constructed at the cost of one,John Middleton,who having been born in Marton and become a wealthy mercer in London,decided that the locals should no longer have to pay a toll.With the completion of the new bridge no payment was demanded of anyone.In 1924 it was noted that the "modern traffic" had made the structure unsafe and a decision was taken by the county council to undertake repair work at a cost of Â£3000.It now stands only 12'6" wide and carries heavy traffic batween Coventy and Banbury.
